Award.AwardTitle: Doctoral Dissertation Research: State Transformations and Family Norms

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Social, Behav & Economic Scie

Division.LongName: Division Of Behavioral and Cognitive Sci

Award.AbstractNarration:
The research supported by this award will investigate religious change in a context of increasing secularism. Much of recent social science research on religious change has focused on societies where increases in religiosity have produced political division and activism, particularly around social policies seen as inconsistent with belief. Less attention has been paid to societies in which religiosity is decreasing as religious citizens support secular social policies that are inconsistent with religious doctrine. Given the impact of religious politics in the contemporary world, it is important to understand both of these trends.

To address this gap in knowledge, University of Chicago anthropology doctoral student Kelsey Robbins, under the supervision of Dr. Jennifer Cole, will investigate a situation in which believers advocate for policies and practices that conflict with the social teachings of their religion. The research will be carried out in the Republic of Ireland. Proposed reforms of Ireland's social legislation, and the debates, activism, and practices that surround them, offer an ideal context for examining these processes of religious change. The researcher will gather data using a variety of anthropological methods, including: participant observation, semi-structured interviews, the collection of life history narratives, and analysis of textual discourse and media. By exploring how Irish citizens make sense of the tensions between their politics, their policy preferences, and the mainstream social teachings of their religion, this project will advance social scientific theory of the relationship between state secularization, religious dissent, and social regulation.

POR.DRECONTENT:
This project explored religious change in the context of increasing secularization. Social scientific research on religious change has primarily focused on contexts where religiosity has increased and where religious citizens actively challenge social policies that are inconsistent with the doctrine of their religion. However, there has been less scholarship on religious change in contexts where religiosity is decreasing and where religious citizens support social policies that are popularly understood to be secular and that may conflict with the main teachings of their faith. 

The Republic of Ireland offered an ideal context for such an investigation. Hotly contested debates around proposed reforms to social legislation prompted some religious citizens to actively advocate for policies and practices that conflicted with the mainstream social teachings of their religion. For twelve months, the researcher explored how these religious citizens made sense of the tensions between their policy preferences and religious doctrine, as well as how religious citizens who desired more consistency between social policy and religious doctrine responded to religious dissent. The researcher employed a variety of anthropological methods including participant observation, semi-structured interviews, and the collection and analysis of textual discourse and media. Insights from this research contribute to social scientific theorizations of state secularization, religious dissent, and social regulation and to a more nuanced and complete understanding of the relationship between religious, political, and social change in the contemporary world.
